search_result.title: 50 years of Muncie Mall: A timeline of retail trends and turnover
search_result.text:
Feb. 12, 2020 Updated June 15, 2021, 4:09 p.m. ET

Throughout its half-century-long history, the Muncie Mall has embodied the economic and social trends of changing times, an impression driven home by a search through its years of local news coverage.

When it was first proposed for the outskirts of town, the new-fangled indoor shopping mall — heavily promoted with the promise of air-conditioning and plenty of free parking — had to battle through zoning issues, years of delays and rumors the project was “dead” before construction finally began.

Luring stores from downtown starting with Sears, the mall was blamed from its earliest days and for decades after for having “killed downtown Muncie.” But by 2020, downtown Muncie had seen an economic resurgence of sorts with restaurants, breweries and other locally owned businesses populating its storefronts, while the mall’s lineup of mostly national chain stores visibly hollowed out — even as McGalliard Road remained a busy commercial strip essentially created by the mall’s presence.

In its earliest incarnation, the mall’s offerings included a drugstore, a supermarket, a fabric store, a pet store and a bank, categories no longer represented among the stores selling clothing, shoes, jewelry and other items now.

Even when some specific businesses in the mall remained through the decades, their offerings gradually changed to fit the era’s expectations. When the mall first opened in 1970, each of its three anchor department stores included its own restaurant; the availability of “ample eating facilities” inside the mall in its early years was blamed in part for the closure of the first restaurant located in the mall’s parking lot, apparently just too far away to tempt hungry shoppers outside. By the ‘80s, clothing stores aimed at “juniors” or “younger women” were increasingly visible among the mall’s offerings that had previously been designated for women, men and children.

By 2020, the periodic closure of yet another Muncie Mall store because of the financial failure of a national or regional company felt like a recent trend that was gathering momentum. But in fact, the mall had seen just such losses within its first decade, as anchors and smaller stores disappeared from its halls, only to be replaced by others. The difference in 2020, however, is the question of what, if anything, might be the replacement this time.

►MALL STORES STATUS: What's the outlook for companies behind some of Muncie Mall's remaining stores?

The '60s: The mall that almost never was

1964: Indianapolis developer Melvin Simon and Associates begins waging "a long hard battle" over zoning to build a shopping mall on 56 acres at McGalliard Road and Granville Avenue, according to The Muncie Star. "Original plans called for a four-story office and medical building, plus three high-rise apartment units," in addition to retail, a 1967 article notes.

April 1965: Muncie government officials and businessmen — including Edmund F. Petty, president of Ball Stores — visit the "brand new air conditioned downtown shopping mall" in Urbana, Ill., looking for ways to revitalize Muncie's downtown. Continued efforts by the "Muncie Foresight" group to boost downtown in subsequent years, even after construction begins on the northeast-side Muncie Mall, ultimately result in the closure of part of Walnut Street downtown for a pedestrian mall, but fail to halt the migration of numerous businesses over the years from the city's center to the mall and the eventual northside business corridor.

January 1967: The metro plan director says a northside shopping mall appears to be dead after rezoning for the land expires, but just two weeks later he reverses that, giving Simon the go-ahead to apply for a building permit.

July 1967: Sears announces it will close its downtown store at 115 S. Walnut St. to move into the new mall.

December 1967: A Muncie Star article about local development — which cites not only the long-awaited Muncie Mall but also plans for a South Walnut Street K-Mart and the nearly-completed Zayres at the Meadows Shopping Center west of downtown — is accompanied by a photo of a "Coming Soon, Muncie Mall Shopping Center" sign in an overgrown field at the corner of McGalliard and Granville.

May 23, 1969: A formal groundbreaking ceremony is held for the "multimillion-dollar Muncie Mall... (a) 550,000-square-foot shopping complex at Granville and McGalliard," The Muncie Evening Press reports. When completed, the mall is slated to have 45 retailers and "service firms" with parking for 3,200 cars. Department stores are Sears, W.T. Grant Co. and Britt's Department Store. Other tenants lined up so far include Standard Supermarket, Osco Drugs, Steck's, Singers, Paul Harris Co., Jonathans, Zales, National Shirt, Kinney Shoes, Goodman Jewelry, Nobil Shoes, Hoyt Wright, Goodyear, Fabric Lane and Neumode Hosiery.

The '70s: Santa, Sears and so much more

February 1970: Mall construction progresses toward a possible grand opening in August, The Muncie Star reports, noting McGalliard and Granville will be altered by the mall developers later in the year to accommodate expected heavier traffic.

Aug. 5, 1970: Sears officially opens its new store, the first Muncie Mall merchant to do so. Muncie Star coverage warns of possible inconvenience for customers during the first few days of Sears' operation since entrance roads from McGalliard to the parking lot are still being completed. Ads for Sears later in the month don't hesitate to promise "acres of free parking." An Evening Press item also published Aug. 5 offers directions for those wondering "How do you get to the Muncie Mall."

September 1970: A Muncie Star article cites the new mall as the major reason that two-lane McGalliard Road has become "a bottleneck" between Wheeling Avenue and Broadway, especially during peak traffic hours. "...With the prospect of the (four-lane) Tillotson-McGalliard extension opening and the increasing traffic to the Muncie Mall, McGalliard Road may prove to be Muncie's road-to-avoid-if-at-all-possible," the article states with startling foresight.

October 1970: Zales Jewelers opens in Muncie Mall at the start of the month at the same corner it still occupies 50 years later, according to a map published in 1970. In mid-October, Britts department store opens off the center court, featuring "the only two-way escalator in Muncie." Grants advertises for a "Doorbuster sale" Oct. 22-24 (a wig case for only $4.44!) at its new Muncie Mall store (later the site of JCPenney).

Nov. 2, 1970: The Goodyear Service Store opens at the mall, offering not only tires and auto service but also G.E. major appliance, TVs and stereos.

November 1970: An ad for Merchants National Bank promotes its new branch in the mall near Sears with a drive-up window in the parking lot.

Nov. 27, 1970: Santa Claus arrives at the new Muncie Mall at 11 a.m., according to an ad in the Thanksgiving paper promoting the appearance the next day. The Thanksgiving ad lists mall businesses open by this time: Merchants National Bank, Steck's Men's Shop, Kinney Shoes, National Shirt, Mode O'Day, Lloyd's Shoes, Osco Drugs, Suzy Boutique, Father and Son Shoe, Zales, Regal Shoes, Regis Beauty Salon, Sears, The Book Shelf, Hickory Farms, Standard Supermarket, Orange Julius, General Nutrition, 33 Flavors Ice Cream, Junior Threads, Michael Thomas, Musicland, Britts, Brooks Fashion, Hoyt Wright, Nobil Shoes, Russell Stover Candies, Neumode Hosiery, Mangels, So-Fro Fabrics, Dean's Magnavox, W.T. Grant, Goodyear, Paul Harris, Singer, Barker's Shoes, Goodman Jewelers, Hot Sam Pretzels and Children's Photographer.

March 1971: Holland House Cafeteria opens by the main entrance, down the hall from the center courtyard and Britts. The restaurant closes in 1975.

June 1971: King's Food Host, a national hamburger chain, opens a standalone restaurant in the mall's parking lot. (During construction, dynamite attached to one of the non-union construction company's trucks in the mall parking lot explodes on a Friday night, shattering windows in the King's building and knocking some mall doors askew.) The restaurant closes in February 1974.

August 1971: In the wake of annexation that makes McGalliard Road the city's responsibility, Mayor Paul Cooley says widening McGalliard to four lanes between Wheeling and Ind. 67 to relieve the traffic bottleneck is a top priority, but finding the funds to do so will take at least two years.

September 1971: A first-anniversary celebration for the mall includes the giveaway of a 1971 Vega.

Oct. 29, 1971: Late-night TV "spook show" host Sammy Terry is featured at the mall's Halloween "Spooktacular," along with a costume parade and contest for kids.

November 1973: Mall merchants announce that Christmas decorations this year will be lighted only during peak customer traffic hours in order to save electricity during the nation's energy crisis.

February 1974: An ad from the Muncie Mall Merchants Association lists current businesses in the mall: The Animal Fair, Barker's Shoe Store, Bresler's 33 Flavors, Britts, Brooks, Check'rd Flag, The Children's Photographer, Dean's Magnavox and Frigidare Center, Grant City, Hickory Farms, Cinderella Shoppes, Holland House Cafeteria, Dr. Tavel, Father and Son Shoes, General Nutrition Center, Goodman Jewelers, Goodyear Service Stores, Hot Sam's Pretzel, Hoyt Wright, Junior Threads, Keros Coney Island, King's Food Host, Kinney Shoes, Lloyd's Shoes, Mangels, Merchants National Bank, Mode O'Day, Motherhood Maternity Shop, Musicland, National Shirt Shop, Neumode Hosiery Shop, Nobil's Shoes, Orange Julius, Osco Drug, The Party House, Paul Harris, Regal Shoe Shop, Regis Beauty Salon, Russell Stover Candies, Sears Roebuck and Co., The Singer Company, So-Fro Fabrics, Stecks, Stecks Tree House, W.K. Stweart Book Store, Sultan's Castle, Tiffany Bakery, Tony's Pipe Towne, Town Finance and Zales Jewelers.

March 1974: A business column in The Muncie Evening Press notes the Muncie Mall's concourse is being used by people who specifically walk laps for exercise, perhaps the first mention of local "mall walkers."

August 1974: Robert Hall Clothes moves into the space previously occupied by Standard Food Market.

June 1975: A consumer survey conducted for Muncie Mall merchants shows about half of the mall's shoppers are from Muncie, and the other half are "mainly (from) Albany, Anderson, Dunkirk, Eaton, Gaston, Hartford City, New Castle, Parker City, Portland, Redkey, Winchester and Yorktown," The Muncie Evening Press reports.

July 1975: The Movies at Muncie Mall, a three-screen United Artists cinema, opens for business, showing "Funny Lady," "Bite the Bullet" and "The Wild McCullochs" its opening weekend.

October 1975: Perkins Pancake and Steak House opens in the former King's Food Host restaurant building in the mall parking lot.

Oct. 31, 1975: About a month after starting bankruptcy proceedings, the struggling W.T. Grant Co. closes 280 of its stores in the Midwest, including both Muncie stores, one at the Southway Plaza and the other in one of the anchor spots at Muncie Mall.

December 1975: MCL Cafeteria opens in the space formerly occupied by Holland House.

December 1976: Plans for a "major facelift" for the mall are announced, including a new color scheme of yellow, beige, burnt orange and brown, live-landscaped seating areas and a fountain in the center commons area in front of Britts, which is "soon to be taken over by L.S. Ayres." The rededication ceremony for the newly renovated mall in April 1977 features celebrity guest Ed McMahon.

January 1977: J.C. Penney moves from its downtown store at Charles and Mulberry streets to the former Grant department store's space at the mall, a move that nearly doubles its floor space and allows the store to offer more than 40 retail departments, a hair salon and a 100-seat restaurant.

April 1977: L.S. Ayres opens at the mall in the former Britts space. Rezoning of land adjacent to Muncie Mall is approved to permit construction of a new building for more retail space, development that eventually becomes Muncie Mall Shoppes to the west along McGalliard.

June 1978: Ball Stores announces plans to open a shop specializing in men's and women's clothing at Muncie Mall while continuing to operate its existing stores downtown and in The Village. Ball will take over the space previously occupied by Robert Hall Clothes and several other nearby storefronts, making it the fourth largest mall retailer, The Muncie Evening Press reports.

1979: Members of the Mall Merchants Association are told confidentially that three more large stores — Block's, Lazarus and Montgomery Ward — will be added in an extension of the mall concourse, The Muncie Evening Press reports. Simon declines to discuss the expansion publicly; a mall manager later says that plan was put on "the back burner."

October 1979: The mall cinema offers midnight showings of "The Rocky Horror Picture Show" every Friday and Saturday night.

The '80s: '53 Muncie Mall merchants to serve you'

December 1980: L.S. Ayres at the Muncie Mall advertises special breakfasts with Santa for kids and senior citizens in its in-store restaurant, and features singers from local schools, churches and other groups caroling through the store during the Christmas shopping season.

August 1982: The mall announces that Tex Critter's Pizza Jamboree, a chain of "youth oriented" restaurants featuring mechanized animals and video games, will open in an empty space next to Sears. That will bring the mall's total occupancy to 58 businesses; the only vacancy is a 250-square-foot stall near Osco Drug, The Muncie Evening Press reports.

February 1983: Naturalizer shoe store opens at Muncie Mall in the spot formerly occupied by Regal Shoes. Sporting goods chain store the Athletic Department announces plans to open that spring in space occupied by Western World, a mall tenant since the mid-1970s that is moving to the long-vacant building last occupied by Perkins Pancakes in the mall's east parking lot.

April 1983: Mutual Home Federal Savings and Loan Association advertises free "play money" demonstrations for those who want to try out its new MoneyMover 24-hour Automatic Teller beside Osco Drug at the Muncie Mall entrance.

November 1983: Tex Critter's Pizza Jamboree closes amid its parent company's financial troubles. The Muncie Evening Press notes the mall is suing the restaurant for back rent.

November 1983: A newspaper ad lists "53 Muncie Mall merchants to serve you": Athletic Dept., Athlete's Foot, L.S. Ayres, Ball Stores, Barker's Shoes, The Bottomhalf, Bresler's 33 Flavors, Brooks Fashions, Check'rd Flag, Cinderella Shoppes/Just Guys, Connie Shoes, Dobbs-Mathew Bootery, Dr. Tavel Vision Center, Earring Tree, Fashion Crossroads, Father and Son Shoes, General Nutrition Center, Goodman Jewelers, Goodyear Service Store, Hot Sam Pretzels, Hoyt Wright, J.C. Penney, Keros Coney Island, Kinney Shoes, Lloyd's Shoes, MCL Cafeteria, Merchants National Bank, Merle Norman Cosmetics, Motherhood Maternity, Musicland, Mutual Home Moneymover, National Shirt Shop, Naturalizer Shoes, Nobil Shoes, Orange Julius, Osco Drugs, Party House, Paul Harris, Peanut Shack, The Pet House, Reader's World, Regis Hairstylists, Russell Stover Candies, Sears, So-Fro Fabrics, Stride-Rite Bootery, Stuarts, Sultan's Castle, Things Remembered, Town Finance, United Artists Cinema, Western World and Zales.

December 1983: Horse-drawn buggy rides for $1 are offered from the main entrance of Muncie Mall to shoppers' cars during the Christmas season.

December 1983: In response to complaints that popular "mall Santa" Betty Lou Schultz — a regular draw since the first Christmas after the mall's opening — isn't appearing at the mall, the marketing director tells The Muncie Evening Press that rather than hiring its own Santa as in past years, the mall is contracting with a different photo company, which has handled its own casting and hired three Ball State students in their mid-20s to play Santa instead.

December 1983: Osco Drug at the mall sponsors an auction of 12 Cabbage Patch Kids dolls in the mall's center court. The mall plans to have extra security on hand "to control anticipated crowds and to escort successful purchasers of Cabbage Patch Kids to their cars," The Muncie Star reports, noting these are expected to be the last Cabbage Patch dolls available in Muncie before Christmas Day.

April 1984: A Ball Stores official says the closure of its downtown Furniture Gallery at 301 S. Walnut St. will allow the company to pump more money into its other three stores, including plans to enlarge the mall location — where it is preparing to sign a new lease — by taking over a vacant shop nearby. A new junior shop opens in the mall store addition in August.

April 1984: A Muncie Mall Walkers Club is established, offering a walkers club ID good for discounts at mall stores.

July 1984: Mr. Video equipment and movie rental store opens at Muncie Mall.

October 1984: Rumors of a mall expansion, perhaps to include a Lazarus, Block's or Kohl's department store, circulate but a spokesman for Simon says expansion is uncertain. A new access road and mall parking lot entrance from McGalliard, west of the old one and equipped with a traffic signal, is opened to traffic with the intention of relieving congestion on McGalliard.

October 1984: Plans are announced for Radio Shack to open in Muncie Mall, in space carved out by reducing the size of the Paul Harris women's and juniorette clothing store. Radio Shack closes its mall store in 1996.

November 1984: The mall adds a toy store, Circus World, in time for Christmas shopping, in the space formerly occupied by Pizza Junction. A number of mall stores offer extended business hours right before the holiday, in keeping with what the mall manager calls a national trend.

January 1985: Goodman Jewelers' Muncie Mall store closes.

March 1985: 16 Plus, a clothing store for young women sizes 16-52 "who enjoy styles from punk to the career look," opens in the former Pizza Junction/Toy Circus spot. Onstage, another clothing store aimed at young women, opens near Sears.

August 1985: Mall owner Melvin Simon and Associates says the company is investigating possible expansion of Muncie Mall, though the expansion is still in the "idea stage."

January 1986: An official with Melvin Simon and Associates says the mall is planning a remodeling and expansion program for 1986-87 that could include the addition of two major department stores and 15-30 small shops to be built on land already owned by Simon, between Ayres and Sears and to the northwest. A Muncie Evening Press article about the plans notes that the mall is valued at $5.5 million and was chosen for expansion because of the strength of the Muncie market.

January 1986: Claire's Boutique leases a storefront formerly occupied by Stride-Rite Shoes.

February 1986: Sycamore, a women's fashion store, opens in the mall.

June 1986: Country Charm Boutique opens in the mall. Berman's The Leather Experts also plans to open, which will leave the mall with just one vacancy: the spot occupied until recently by Russell Stover Candies.

October 1986: The Clock Shop and Blondie's Cookies open in the mall, and existing tenant The Athlete's Foot changes its name to The Finish Line.

December 1986: The city pushes ahead with plans for a long-in-the-works eastside street improvement project that will include a mall entrance at Princeton Avenue and moving the railroad crossing at Granville and Dartmouth to Princeton as well.

August 1987: Mall officials announce plans for a $20 million expansion project to include more than 50 new stores. The project will enlarge the mall and also build a nearby shopping center, and is expected to begin in spring 1988 and finish in 1989. A Simon executive calls Muncie Mall "one of our better locations" in the Midwest.

September 1987: Muncie City Council approves annexing into city limits about 57 acres of land northwest of Muncie Mall to allow Simon to proceed with its $20 million expansion plan.

September 1987: Ball Stores at the mall adds Standt's Fine Jewelry to its in-store offerings. Ben Delk, owner of Standt's, is one of the investors purchasing Ball Stores from the Edmund F. Petty family in 1984.

Oct. 21, 1987: Fire levels a two-story portion of the Muncie Mall Shoppes to the west of the mall, destroying the space occupied by 18 businesses. The structure is rebuilt with just one story.

August 1988: The mall's $20 million expansion plan is halted, with no department store yet having agreed to anchor the proposed mall addition and Simon dropping plans to build a new strip plaza to the northwest and an ice rink to the northeast. A Simon official calls the strip plaza "a definite future, future, future project."

August 1989: Hoyt Wright announces it will close its Muncie Mall store because of declining sales.

August 1989: The Inside Scoop candy store opens in the mall. It closes in 2007.

October 1989: Ball Stores is sold to Elder-Beerman Stores after going into foreclosure. The Muncie Mall store is the last remaining outlet for Ball Stores, which closed the downtown department store in 1986, the Village Collegienne Shops in 1988 and a New Castle store in September 1989, The Muncie Star reports. The mall manager says the mall had been looking at Elder-Beerman for a while to expand its offerings. Elder-Beerman opens in the former Ball space at the mall later in October.

November 1989: Phar Mor Drugs and Child World toy store are announced as anchor tenants for a $15 million open-air shopping center, to be called Muncie Town Plaza, that Simon plans to build north of Muncie Mall. Construction is planned to begin in 1990; some trees are cleared from the property but the mall manager says in May 1990 that construction likely will be delayed until 1991. Ultimately the project stalls.

November 1989: Lenscrafters opens in the mall, as does men's clothing retailer Harry Levinson, which goes into the space vacated by Hoyt Wright.

The '90s: Renovations and a competitor arrives

January 1990: Triple Play sports collectibles store opens at the mall, while Country Charm moves to a different location in the mall and Standt's Fine Jewelers, previously operating inside Elder-Beerman (and before that Ball Stores) moves into its own storefront.

May 1990: Docktor Pet Centers closes at Muncie Mall; the mall manager says they'd like to bring in another pet store but it's difficult since few pet store chains are left.

July 1990: Complaining about being "jerked around" by the Muncie Mall's owners through years of delays in and changes to the Muncie Town Plaza project, the Muncie Redevelopment Commission suspends work on a TIF district to fund $1.7 million in street improvements at the mall, The Muncie Star reports.

August 1990: United Artists Theaters sells the Movies at Muncie Mall three-screen cinema to Goodrich Theaters.

January 1991: So-Fro Fabrics, one of the mall's original tenants, moves to a larger space across Broadway. Similarly, Reader's World moves from the mall to a larger space at Northwest Plaza, but mall management announces plans to bring in another book store, Bookland, which opens in March.

March 1991: Luca Pizza opens near J.C. Penney. On a far more short-term basis, Indiana Michigan Power uses the mall's center court for a temporary emergency service center to handle power outage reports after an ice storm knocks out power to as many as 20,000 local customers.

June 1991: Sultan's Castle arcade moves from a spot next to MCL Cafeteria to the corridor near Muncie Mall 3 Cinema.

July 1991: A Muncie Star article notes that the mall has gone from 20-year leases when it opened to standard leases of 5-10 years, and that it declines to negotiate new agreements with older merchants who refuse to update or remodel their stores.

October 1991: Managers for L.S. Ayres and Muncie Mall discuss still-sketchy plans to renovate and expand the Muncie store. A Muncie Evening Press article refers to Ayres plans from 1987 to build onto its current store in conjunction with a mall expansion that didn't happen, as well as the indefinite postponement of the mall's more recent renovation plans.

November 1991: Andrews Jewelers opens in the former Father and Son Shoes storefront, across from Zales, while the shoe store moves next to Osco Drug Store.

September 1992: Dollar Time, a chain selling items for $1, opens in space formerly occupied by Marjax sporting goods at the north end of the mall.

July 1993: Foot Locker opens at the mall.

July 1994: In keeping with new policy by owner Simon Property Group, Muncie Mall bans smoking.

July 1994: City officials say the long-promised new entrance to the mall off Broadway at Princeton will be postponed yet again because the city has decided to spend those federal funds elsewhere, and Simon has not supplied a deed to the last right-of-way properties needed to begin construction.

November 1994: Muncie Mall gets an in-county competitor in the new Indiana Factory Shops outlet mall in Daleville. By 2004, however, Indiana Factory Shops has lost most of its tenants and switches from retail to a business center.

1995: J.C. Penney's Muncie store gets a facelift, adding a main aisle and widening other paths through the store.

October 1995: Sears has a grand re-opening ceremony for its newly remodeled store at the mall, after adding more than 19,000 square feet of retail space, part of a company-wide makeover promotion.

November 1995: Suncoast Motion Picture Co. opens in the mall, selling movies on VHS and laserdisc.

January 1996: After more than 20 years in Muncie Mall, the Earring Tree closes when its company files for bankruptcy.

March 1996: Simon Property Group unveils a $21 million, nine-month expansion and renovation of Muncie Mall, including a new 120,000-foot L.S. Ayres store, 42,000 additional square feet of retail space and new entrances.

March 1996: Hat World opens in the mall.

April 1996: Mall officials tell the Muncie Redevelopment Commission about a two-phase plan, the first part the mall expansion, and the second construction of a strip mall and movie theater and infrastructure improvement including building the long-discussed extension of Princeton Road around the mall and giving that road to the city.

April 1996: Jay Jacobs clothing store opens in the former Harry Levinson storefront.

June 1996: Bath and Body Works opens in the mall.

Nov. 13, 1996: The new L.S. Ayres opens in space 50 percent larger than its old store.

February 1997: The mall announces Victoria's Secret will open near Sears.

April 1997: While its company reorganizes under Chapter 11 bankruptcy, Elder-Beerman confirms it will occupy both its current space at Muncie Mall, near J.C. Penney, using that for its home furnishings store, and the two-level space left vacant when L.S. Ayres moved to the new wing of the mall in 1996. The home store later moves in with the other departments.

May 1997: Mall owner Simon DeBartolo Property Group sues Kerasotes Theatres, which leases the three-screen theater inside the mall, over Kerasotes' efforts to stop construction of a new cinema. The two sides later reach an out-of-court settlement.

June 1997: Auntie Anne's Hand-Rolled Pretzels opens in the mall.

July 1997: Outback Steakhouse opens by the mall's east entrance in a new building at the site of the former Western World.

Summer 1997: Squeeze Play sports collectibles store opens in the mall, and existing mall stores Claire's and Finish Line move to larger stores in the new L.S. Ayres hallway. Also opening in the Ayres hallway are Kay Jewelers in August, Wooden Key Hallmark by early September, American Eagle Outfitters in September, and Lane Bryant in October.

Oct. 17, 1997: Muncie Mall has a ribbon-cutting followed by a weekend-long grand reopening to celebrate its expansion to 654,000 square feet and 65 tenants. "Stores like American Eagle, Bath and Body Works, Victoria's Secret and Lane Bryant probably wouldn't have located here if we hadn't remodeled," the mall manager says in a Star Press article. A map of the newly expanded mall in The Star Press lists all the occupants at the time: Osco Drug Store, Auntie Anne's Pretzels, Andrews Jewelers, New York New York, Earth Magic, Wilson's The Leather Experts, Lenscrafters, Kinney Shoes, Maurice's, Kay Bee Toys, Country Charm, Fannie May, San Francisco Music Box, Bookland, Paul Harris, Foot Locker, County Seat, Northern Reflections, Kay Jewelers, Hat World, Claire's, Spencer's, Planet Earth, Barb's Country Gifts, Finish Line, Art Nails, Luca Pizza, Inside Scoop, Sam Goody, Goodyear Auto Service Center, Party House, Country Charm Christmas, The Buckle, Jay Jacobs, Payless Shoe Source, Sultan's Castle, General Nutrition Center, Salsa, Day by Day, Squeeze Play, MCL Cafeteria, Mastercuts, Suncoast Motion Picture Company, Bath and Body Works, Dr. Tavel Vision Center, Blondie's Cookies, Zales Jewelers, Fashion Police, Standt's Fine Jewelry, Hot Sam Pretzels, Orange Julius, Time Flyzs, Spirit Vision, West Coast Airbrush, Van Ausdall and Farrar, Afterthoughts, Things Remembered, Grand Illusion, Piercing Pagoda, Warming House, Sunglass Hut, Purple Rain, Devines Coffee and Tea, Muncie Mall Cinema 3, Victoria's Secret, Lane Bryant, Gadzooks, American Eagle Outfitter, Rack Room Shoes, The Wooden Key Hallmark and Irving Computing, plus anchor stores Sears, L.S. Ayres, Elder-Beerman and J.C. Penney. Three storefronts are listed as vacant.

November 1997: T.J. Maxx opens in the new Muncie Town Plaza, the first tenant in the strip mall near Muncie Mall, followed by Office Max in December, Shoe Carnival in March 1998 and Kohl's in April 1998.

April 1998: Eddie Bauer and B Moss clothing stores open in the mall.

Summer 1998: Earth Inc., "a science and nature store," announces it will open in the Ayres hallway in the coming months, while Englin's Fine Footwear opens there in June. Muncie Town Plaza is slated to add The Learning Well school supply store and Catherine's plus-size women's clothing store.

September 1999: Standt's Fine Jewelry announces it will close its mall store and expand its operations downtown and in Winchester.

October 1999: Aeropostale opens in the former Kinney Shoes space.

The new millennium: Beepers, movies and new neighbors

February 2000: Beeper Depot opens at the mall, with ads offering a special grand opening deal that includes "a free digital phone."

March 2000: Old Navy opens at Muncie Mall in the space previously occupied by the Elder-Beerman Home Store.

September 2000: Muncie Mall's three-screen cinema goes dark after Kerasotes Theaters opts not to renew its lease.

February 2001: Paul Harris, one of Muncie Mall's original tenants, closes months after its parent company files for bankruptcy.

Spring 2001: Gap and Gap Kids stores open in the mall. Amid their company's struggles with falling sales, the local stores close and reopen in the mall in March 2007 as Gap Outlet, which closes for good in 2013.

March 2002: Children's Place opens in the storefront left empty after Paul Harris closed a year earlier.

May 2002: Nex Gen teen clothing store opens in the J.C. Penney hall. The mall announces Christopher & Banks and C.J. Banks will open in in the fall in space on the Ayres hall previously occupied by Eddie Bauer, which closed in April.

July 2002: Mall management announces Maurice's will open in Muncie Plaza within two months, while The Limited Too girls' store will open in the mall in October.

Late 2002: The Muncie Mall cinema reopens as a "Dollar Movies" theater, showing second-run movies until June 2005.

December 2002: While local government officials struggle to get a countywide smoking ban passed, MCL Cafeteria at the mall chooses to go smoke-free, The Star Press reports.

Jan. 31, 2003: First Merchants Bank closes its branch in the mall. Officials for the bank, which had been at the mall since the shopping complex opened 30+ years earlier, say the bank didn't want to close its mall branch, but it was told by Simon Properties the mall needed the parking lot space used for the drive-thru.

March 2003: Target opens in its new store just west of Muncie Mall, moving out of the smaller store at the west end of McGalliard Road where it had been for 24 years.

November 2004: Charlotte Russe women's clothing store opens in the mall in space previously held by Kay Bee Toys, which closed earlier in the year after its national company filed for bankruptcy, and Foot Locker, which moves to another storefront in the mall.

December 2004: Dick's Bodacious BBQ opens in the former Goodyear Tire space along the west side of the mall, but closes after just nine months.

March 2005: Osco announces it will close its Muncie Mall drugstore in August; a spokesman for the company says business has declined at the mall site as customers have come to demand the convenience of standalone drugstores and drive-thrus. Osco was the 11th retailer to open at the mall in 1970, The Star Press reports.

March 2005: L.S. Ayres' parent company is bought out, eventually resulting in the store's name being changed to Macy's.

June 2005: A new, 12-screen movie theater opens between Target and Muncie Mall Plaza.

Summer 2005: New York New York men's clothing store in the mall closes.

2006: Sam Goody's music store, Suncoast video store and Friedman's Jewelers close their Muncie Mall stores amid corporate-level financial problems.

May 2006: Books-a-Million opens in the former Osco space at the mall.

May 2007: Rockcycle, a local company making clothing and decor from old vinyl records and album covers, opens a store in Muncie Mall, and another in Castleton Mall in Indianapolis a few months later. By May 2008, however, the company closes both stores and returns to operating as wholesale business, noting that maintaining mall retail space is pricey and "kind of crazy" for them.

September 2007: Ball Memorial Hospital opens Cardinal Quick Care in the mall. The walk-in medical clinic closes in 2009 due to a lack of enough patients to sustain it.

November 2007: MC Sports opens in the Muncie Town Plaza storefront left vacant by the closing of Office Max in 2006. The sporting goods store closes in 2016.

January 2008: Rack Room Shoes closes in the mall, and its space is taken over by an expansion for American Eagle Outfitters.

September 2008: Solution BMX Skateshop opens in the mall, catering to skateboarders and BMX bike riders.

November 2008: Asian Best Cuisine opens in the mall in the former Inside Scoop candy store's space.

July 2009: Longtime mall tenant Dr. Tavel Family Eye Care Center moves from Muncie Mall to Northwest Plaza.

January 2009: In what becomes a familiar refrain among national chains with local stores, Macy's announces store closings, which do not include Muncie's store this time around, but "economists and retail experts say the national recession and a big slow-down in consumer spending will undoubtedly prompt more retailers to close locations," The Star Press reports.

September 2009: The mall has five vacant storefronts, including two larger spaces (the former barbecue restaurant near J.C. Penney and the former medical clinic near Sears), according to the mall's manager.

2010s: Store closures, financial struggles

March 2010: Old Navy closes, at a time when the mall has about half a dozen empty storefronts already.

April 2010: Kohl's, often cited as one of the most successful stores in the Muncie Mall area, is slated for a $950,000 renovation project.

May 2010: AMC buys the Showplace 12 theater near Muncie Mall from Kerasotes.

November 2010: Muncie Mall is on board with ever-earlier openings for Black Friday shopping, announcing the mall's doors and at least one anchor store, Elder-Beerman, will open at 3 a.m. the day after Thanksgiving, with all other mall stores open by 5 a.m. That's in addition to Sears being open 7 a.m.-noon on Thanksgiving.

March 2011: Muncie Mall announces Shoe Dept. Encore will fill the large storefront left vacant by Old Navy's closure a year ago.

August 2011: The Muncie Mall's Elder-Beerman becomes Carson's, a sister store owned by the same company. On another wing of the mall, Kitchen Collection opens down the hall from Macy's; the kitchen supply chain closes all its stores nationwide, including the Muncie store, by the end of 2019.

Fall 2011: Carter's Nearly World Famous Hot Dogs opens in the space previously occupied by Asian Best Cuisine in the J.C. Penney hallway. Carter's closes in 2014.

November 2011: Best Buy Mobile opens in a small storefront next to Carson's. Best Buy closes all of its nearly 250 mobile phone stores, including the one in Muncie Mall, in 2018.

November 2012: In keeping with the trend among retailers, Muncie Mall bumps its Black Friday opening time even earlier, to midnight Thanksgiving, and the mall manager tells The Star Press, "It's turned into Thursday now. I don't ever see it going back to 5 a.m. Friday." Sure enough, by 2013, opening time is 8 p.m. on Thanksgiving.

Winter 2013: On the heels of the Gap Outlet closing at the mall, Dressbarn opens in the vacated storefront near Sears. In May 2019, Dressbarn announces the closing of all its stores, including the Muncie Mall one.

November 2013: Cuidad Colonial Mexican restaurant moves into Muncie Mall, occupying a space previously used by Dick's Bodacious Bar-B-Q, and before that the Goodyear store that closed in the early 2000s.

December 2013: Simon Property Group announces it will spin off 54 of its strip centers and 44 malls in 23 states, including Muncie Mall and Muncie Town Plaza, into a new company to allow Simon to focus on its large malls, including Castleton Square in Indianapolis.

May 2014: Simon sells the Muncie Mall to WP Glimcher.

Summer 2014: Yankee Candle Company opens in the mall; it closes by 2019.

September 2014: With much fanfare, Dick's Sporting Goods opens in the new Muncie Marketplace strip mall west of the Muncie Mall, followed by neighbors Michael's craft store, Five Below, McAlister's Deli and other businesses in smaller, outlot spaces for the strip mall.

April 2015: The Wooden Key Hallmark Store at the mall, which opened in 1997, closes.

May 2015: rue21, a clothing store that opened in the mall in 2008, holds a grand reopening for its enlarged, renovated space.

September 2016: Tony's Pizza has a ribbon-cutting at the corner spot near JCPenney that had been occupied by Pizza di Roma for more than a decade until summer 2016. In July 2018, the mall sues Tony's for allegedly not paying its rent.

November 2017: Brew pub Redemption Alewerks opens a beer kiosk in front of Macy's at Muncie Mall, offering craft beer and food. The business is gone within a year.

November 2017: The AMC Showplace theater adds a bar — having been approved for a liquor license — and renovates the entire complex to add an IMAX theater, recliner seating and ticketless entry.

February 2018: Torrid clothing store opens in the mall.

April 2018: JCPenney at the mall files for a building permit for a $250,000 remodeling project to add a Sephora cosmetics section in the store.

April 2018:The closure of the Carson's at Muncie Mall is announced, months after its parent company, Bon-Ton, filed for bankruptcy.

May 2018:Sears, the last of Muncie Mall's original anchor stores, will close by September, its financially struggling parent company announces. The loss of Sears and Carson's leave the mall without two of its four anchors.

►COLUMN: Sears was ahead of its time. Then the 21st century arrived

July 2018: GameStop opens in the Muncie Marketplace strip mall, but does not plan to close its store in the nearby Muncie Mall (having instead closed one near Lowe's at the other end of McGalliard Road). Another Muncie Mall tenant, Kay Jewelers, moves out of the mall and into another storefront in the nearby strip mall.

April 2019: Charlotte Russe, a mall tenant since 2004, closes as part of a companywide shutdown of all the chain's stores. Similarly, Payless Shoe Source also closed all of its stores, including the Muncie Mall one, after filing for bankruptcy.

►'DOMINO EFFECT': Muncie Mall's fate more questionable after continued store closings

April 2019: The Star Press reports that the 2018 annual report for Muncie Mall's current owner, real estate investment trust Washington Prime Group, listed the mall as one of the group's Tier 2 properties, "viable enclosed retail properties with lower productivity and modest growth profiles," A footnote in the annual report, however, stated that Muncie Mall would be reclassified as a non-core property (no longer needed/essential) in 2019, potentially meaning the owner would remove the property from its assets by handing it back to the bank that holds its $33.9 million mortgage.

December 2019: Panera Bread opens the new restaurant it has built in the southwest corner of the Muncie Mall parking lot near JCPenney, moving from its previous location in a strip mall next door.

December 2019: Cuidad Colonial closes.

2020s: What's ahead for Muncie Mall?

January 2020: Macy's announces it will close its Muncie Mall store.

January 2020: While Macy's liquidates its stock, the former Sears and Carson's anchor spaces sit empty, along with at least eight smaller storefronts and the former attached (walled off from the main corridor) movie theater space. Retailers operating at the start of the mall's 50th year include Louie's Tux Shop, Serenity Spa, Nirvana, Finish Line, Squeeze Play, American Eagle Outfitters, Christopher Banks, CJ Banks, Justice, Spencer's Gifts, Journeys, Lane Bryant, Foot Locker, Claire's, Tradehome, Lids, Victoria's Secret Pink, GameStop, Aeropostale, Torrid, This 'N' That, Hot Topic, Children's Place, Books-A-Million, FYE, Auntie Anne's, Zales, MCL Cafeteria, Icing, Francesca's, Bath and Body Works, Buckle, Art Spa, Country Charm, Seals Furniture, GNC, Blondie's Cookies, two kiosks selling phone accessories, Shoe Dept. Encore, rue21, Smoothie Hut, Ann's Nail salon and JCPenney.

Feb. 11, 2020: The City of Muncie announces on Facebook that Old Navy will return, almost exactly 10 years after closing at Muncie Mall, but instead of the mall this time the store reportedly will go into a nearby strip mall.

March 21, 2020: Amid the COVID-19 pandemic and resulting stay-at-home orders, the mall announces it is closing until further notice, although many of its remaining stores have already halted business by that point.

May 14, 2020: Muncie Mayor Dan Ridenour announces Muncie Mall will reopen May 18 under new management.

June 4, 2020: The Muncie Mall JCPenney store is among 154 locations listed to close permanently, according to a bankruptcy court filing by the struggling JCPenney company.

July 2020: Justice, a girls' clothing store, holds a closeout sale at its Muncie Mall location, while the mall's Lane Bryant store is one of more than 150 nationwide (though the only one in Indiana) on a list of outlets slated to close. Other recent closures at the mall include Wireless Toybox, Art Spa and Nirvana.

September 2020: Ball State University's Urban Planning program sets up shop in the former Dress Barn/Gap storefront, transforming the space into a community design center where students can host meetings, conduct research and interact with residents to help community leaders develop a comprehensive plan for Delaware County.

Fall 2020: Muncie Mall petitions the Delaware County's assessor's office seeking a reduction in the mall's current assessed value of $20,684,100 based on the number of vacancies.

Winter 2021: Muncie Mall's owner, Washington Prime Group, owner is reported to be preparing to file for bankruptcy. The impact that could have on the local mall isn't immediately obvious.

April 2021: Old Navy, which closed its store inside Muncie Mall in 2010, opens in a nearby strip mall in the spot formerly occupied by MC Sports.

May 2021: While setting up an Economic Development Target Area at the mall to promote development, city officials say two retailers plan to open in or near the mall: Buyer's Market off-price retailer in the former Macy's, and Burlington Coat Factory along Princeton Avenue across from the mall.

June 14, 2021: Washington Prime Group files for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection after months of struggling to meet debt obligations.

search_result.text:
Oct. 13, 2022 Updated Oct. 17, 2022, 5:01 p.m. ET

Editor's Note: One sentence was fixed to clarify that items in the John and Virginia Duncan collection will be available for auction at Everard Auctions this weekend in Savannah.

Though not centrally situated on Monterey Square, the yellow, natural stucco four-story row house at 12 E. Taylor St. certainly has a view of everything. From the large parlor floor windows, a curious person can catch the hustle and bustle of the square — tourists snapping photos in front of Mercer House, worshippers filing into Mikve Israel, horse-drawn carriages clomping, and the not-so-occasional trolley slowing to give a glimpse of history.

For nearly 50 years, John Duncan watched and delighted in Monterey Square's comings and goings, its changes and its scandals. He often stood outside his home, where the garden level doubled as a shop filled with historic ephemera, and regaled tourists with talk of "Midnight" and the unusual historical bits that trolley guides often overlooked. His neighborhood changed over the years, with die-hard downtowners ceding to seasonal renters, and Armstrong students disappearing as pierced-and-tattooed art students passed by with portfolios tucked under their arms.
